narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  He gave a good and interesting course lecture on the day he was assigned. He was accessible and quick to respond to emails.
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Good tutor but I would have liked him to integrate more with the class.
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Didn't interact with him much
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Great all round
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  He was good.
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew was great, no real recommendations to make here.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: At first I thought the text was a bit too simple, but complemented with the scientific research articles, it was just right.
Material was suited more towards undergraduate students

Professor Comita is a good teacher, and genuinely cares that her students are engaged in the material and learning. That being said, I think the course could have moved a bit more quickly/ at a higher level and been a bit less lecture-based.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I really enjoyed the subject matter, which was a new area for me. I liked that we had guest lectures mixed in, and that we incorporated recent research findings.

I liked how concepts from different lectures were linked together to illustrate bigger pictures. I also liked how we considered conservation issues from multiple perspectives to think about what would or would not work and why. It definitely changed my opinions on some things.
Lecturers who presented in our class, classmates presentations, the book.
The inclusions of material from a variety of sources such as scientific papers, guest speakers and text-books as well as incorporation of different perspectives
The best aspects of this course is after reading background information from the textbook, we read and related the information to real world events and journals.
A few of the guest lecturers were very dynamic. I particularly enjoyed the lectures about fig-wasp mutualism and savannah/woodland interfaces.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The assignments piled up at the end of the course. Probably no need for a presentation, research guide, homework, and final to all be due within 1 1/2 weeks of each other-- this could be spaced out.
More classroom debate/discussion; introduce some provocative topics or controversial findings. I think it would be more engaging and challenging than the current structure.
Professor, organization, readings, final project
More organization of the schedules, at the beginning of the course communications were a little confusing, the weekly assignments were a bit boring.

Many of the sessions were very lecture-based, and often covered similar content to what was in the course text. I think we could either have gone deeper into the concepts we studied or covered more material, though. I also appreciate Professor Comita's attempt to integrate discussion and activities into the class but it didn't always work. Perhaps asking more provocative questions?

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Students weren't always engaged in the group discussions of papers. Finding different ways to get them to interact in the discussion or read the papers thoroughly would help the learning and discussion process.
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is my first tropical ecology course. I have a policy and social science background, but hope to move more into the ecology field so this was a great intro.
I will be working in tropical forests for my research
It gave me foundations for my future work/research on tropical forests.

I'm interested in working in conservation and development in the developing world, particularly in the tropics. I didn't major in hard science in my undergraduate studies and wanted a firmer grasp of tropical ecology.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to complement my social sciences background with a better understanding of the natural sciences, as I hope to merge the two in my future career. I also plan to work in tropical areas where tropical forests are a major resource.
I thought it would provide me with new material

I am a public health student interested in wildlife disease epidemiology. This class was important for me because I want to work on research that links ecological concepts to the emergence of infectious diseases from wildlife to humans. It was a great way for me to get a solid foundation that goes beyond a basic intro ecology course.
Because I want to focus in tropical forest conservation and management.
Personal interest.
I took this course because I have a strong background in ecology and research. I plan to one day conducting research in the tropics.
See #20

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I feel much more comfortable conversing on the class topics on other areas of my academic and professional work.
No
Yes. I was pleasantly surprised at how much about ecology I didn't already know. It was definitely worth my time.
Yes
Yes
Yes.
Generally, yes, although I thought this would be a higher level ecology course, whereas it often felt more like an introductory course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Integrating with my classmates, learning from them!!
NA

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I'd recommend it. The workload is fair and the information is interesting if you haven't covered these topics before. If you're already somewhat familiar, I'd suggest taking a different, more advanced ecology class.
Don't
Don't miss classes and take advantage of the invited lecturers presentations.
Do the readings, bring interesting real-world problems to class
Take it.

Great for students who are looking for a primer on ecology of tropical rainforests, but not for those with a significant background in the basic concepts already. Focuses almost entirely on tropical rainforests as opposed to other tropical forests, which may be frustrating to those interested in dry forests and woodland systems.
